page.title: 08The Vegetation of Knockholt
page.content: The varied soils show a wide variety of vegetation. The chalk scarp slope and clay dip slopes showing marked differences. On the chalk the woodland is predominately beech with yew, holly cherry, whitebeam and some oaks. In Autumn traveller's joy is noticeable. On the clay the woods are mostly oak with ash, hawthorn, field maple and many others in thickets with dense undergrowth and bracken, honeysuckle and wild roses in the hedgerows. In Spring bluebells and primroses are very common, though the ploughing of old pastures has greatly reduced the range of flowers to be seen. Orchids, violets, harebells and cowslips can be found and recently himalayan balsam. Blackberries, elderberries and sloes are gathered in the Autumn.The height of the area means that Spring flowers are later than in neighbouring areas.
